metadata.name: serendipity vs consequence #161
metadata.description:
This work is the result of a deterministic algorithm which manifests differently depending on the device it is viewed upon.  

The basis for the project is a phenomenon called z-fighting, a common issue in 3d graphics that appears when two or more objects overlap in 3d space. The graphic drivers on a device cannot determine which  object is closer or farther from the viewpoint since they were in exactly the same place. If we consider reality to be a continuum including our physical and digital experiences, z-fighting is a strictly digital phenomenon as objects trying to occupy the same physical space usually have tragic or intimate consequences.

The work in the current generative art movement is based on deterministic algorithms. This means that given a set of input parameters, the result should be exactly the same. This ideal is hardly ever the case as the code behind the art goes through different processing steps, on different CPUs, rendered on different GPUs, and interpreted by different graphics drivers. The code in this project is deterministic, it includes no conditions to adapt one way or the other to any particular hardware device, yet due to how the varying hardware and software devices try to mitigate z-fighting, this same code generates an entirely different experience on different devices.

To further exploit the nuances of these consequences, this work generates an audio score based on the generated graphics, analysing the canvas with a clustering algorithm and converting color values to notes, volume, and distortion.

A back-end system has been developed to render out each iteration across a variety of devices. To explore this catalog, please visit: 
https://fraguada.net/svsc/

More information about the project in the fx(text) article:
https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/serendipity-vs-consequence

Slowly developed between May 2022 and March 2023.

~interacting~

click or tap on the artwork canvas to enable audio. audio starts a few seconds after initiating the work.

~ui~
double click or double tap to open the project ui

‚§° - toggle fullscreen
img - save png. please wait for the capture to complete
vid - save webm. saves a 34 second clip with audio

~console~
open the development console on desktop browser for more information on the iteration

The console includes more information about a particular iteration, including parameter values, palette information, and information on some url params you can play with.
Once the audio starts, you can also see an audio score as coloured bars.

~acknowledgements~

To my family and friends for allowing me time and giving me support throughout the development of this project.

~license~

This artwork would not be possible without the collective efforts of many individuals developing open source software. 

three.js, tone.js, RecordRTC, chroma.js, skmeans, html2canvas, file-saver, ua-parser.js

metadata.name: Traveler #96
metadata.description:
Retro sci-fi style landscape sketch drawn by code.

Features:
- Terrain: Cliff, Cavern, Sky, Megalopolis, Desert, Sea, Space, Volcano
- Orientation: Landscape, Portlait
- Palette: White, Cream, Tan, Pink, Green, Yellow, Orange
- Background: Light, Dark

Live view options:
- Press "s" key: Saves the high resolution image (4200 x 3300 for landscape, 3300 x 4200 for portlait)

Depending on the device you run it on, it may take some time for the drawing to complete.
Made with p5js.

June 2022
ykxotkx

metadata.name: Algorithm, be my guide #177
metadata.description:
At length, I summoned the courage to approach.

-

I was worn. Months of aimless wandering have culminated in this series; a meditation on my struggles to find a direction in my life and with my art.

At times paralyzed by too many possibilities, and at other times completely void of ideas. I was lost in the depths of my thinking, overwhelmed by indecision and doubt.

Generative works are a form of process art, yet along the way I‚Äôd forgotten to ‚Äútrust the process‚Äù. It was time to cede control and let each line of code light the way.

-

This project paints on a 2D canvas, pixel by pixel. I used a custom projection that blends isometric and perspective techniques, to create an uncanny viewpoint between the two. Objects are randomly generated, then an algorithm applies color mixing and position displacement to each pixel as it‚Äôs rendered.

By default the canvas has 2k pixels on its longest edge. You can change this in live view by pressing any number from 1-9. For example, pressing ‚Äò4‚Äô would render it with 4k pixels along the longest edge. I recommend ‚Äò4‚Äô, but this can take up to a few minutes to render.

Press ‚Äòs‚Äô to save the rendered image.

metadata.name: Glide #12
metadata.description: Packed circles on the move.

metadata.name: reborn #41
metadata.description:
This is an album of cities too ideal to ever materialise.

It consists of 256 algorithmically generated plans that resemble drawings of Vincenzo Scamozzi, Pietro Cataneo, Filarete and other theorists of the Italian Renaissance. The cities differ in size, the grid of the streets, the landscape around them and the people that inhabit their utopian walls. They carry names that are Italian exonyms of real European cities, drawing a vision of a different world that enacts a mixture of military perfection with social superiority. Flawless, harmonious, unconquerable and utterly impossible.

History brought us many theories about ideal cities, but very few examples exist today. Italian Palmanova or Polish Zamo≈õƒá are the few to remind us how hard it is to shape reality according to ideals. When confronted with the material world, its idealism becomes the city's grates foe.

To zoom, press a mouse button over the image or touch the screen. To pan, keep the mouse pressed and move it around.

objkt.name: How And How Not To Maintain Friendships #15

metadata.name: How And How Not To Maintain Friendships #15
metadata.description:
How and How Not To Maintain Friendships charts the ways that relationships between people can develop or dissipate over time. Starting from different places, and different degrees of distance or closeness, friendships evolve over time. Sometimes we grow closer to others, sometimes we grow apart. Sometimes this happens quickly, and other times it is slow. Sometimes we become so enmeshed in our friends‚Äôs lives that our paths twist together, interlocking and criss-crossing in a shared journey. Other times we may follow mostly parallel paths with a handful of others, some of whom may head off on their own paths at different points down the line. Each of us influences the many people around us in different ways. Like masses suspended in space, friendship works like gravity on the people close to us, sometimes bringing us closer together and sometimes sending us whirling off in new directions.

2022 by LIA (www.liaworks.com)

Token-holder's usage rights:
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

issuer.name: How And How Not To Maintain Friendships

metadata.name: Sequence #99
metadata.description:
Sequence by Hevey (@HeveyArt).

This artwork was created using p5js.

metadata.name: Supernal Memories #219
metadata.description:
With its layered bursts of color, light, and shadow, Supernal Memories carries an underlying message of optimism through its harmony of seeming dualities ‚Äì hard and soft, familiar and surprising, expression and introspection.

Each newly generated circle brings its own energy, creating layered groups of light that sometimes resemble phenomena like nebula, lightning sprites, and auras ‚Äì ethereal whispers of something remembered. 

Supernal Memories is an invitation to observe the forms & feel of each piece without labeling their qualities, to contemplate the infinite possibilities of the universe, and to explore the depths of your imagination.


--

Created by Diego Pintos @DondiegoTez
Creative collaboration with Tender @tender_art

To get a high resolution file, add "&print=14000" to the end of the live URL / hash, using any resolution number that fits your needs. Press 's' to save the file when it is done loading.

Press 'p' to continue the animation for another variation.

100% code, made with p5.js
See license.md

metadata.name: Regular Shapes #4
metadata.description:
A fragment shader written to boggle the mind, starting out as a simple 3D rotating shape but ending in a crazy composition of that same shape morphed into a new life.

Features different color schemes, shapes and speeds.

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #262
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. ‚ÄúThe Bugged Tree‚Äù‚Äôs code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren‚Äôt under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there‚Äôs a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: Richter #18
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press ‚Äús‚Äù to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: Spring will be back again  #7
metadata.description:
This project aims to capture the essence of the Japanese hanami experience where people gather to admire the fleeting beauty of the cherry blossom.

It's a representation of the beauty of an unreal nature where the details of the leaves and flowers are imaginary and always different.

While some trees in the animation are depicted in full bloom with delicate petals and lush leaves, other may yet have to blossom or may already have lost their blooms, or even don't have leaves or flowers at all.

Crafted entirely with lines of code in vanilla javascript, without the use of reference images or templates.

There are over 20 distinct features that define each token and the animation is also interactive

Each time the animation is played, it generates a unique and dynamic display of the blossom trees, while still maintaining the features defined by the underlying token.

You may also change the resolution or the layout at any time, or toggle the animation mode.



Commands

[1] Low resolution
[2] Normal resolution
[3] High res
[4] Super high res
[5] Print res (not animated)

[a] or [space] Reload in animation mode
[s] Reload in static mode
[d] Download snapshot in current resolution

Change layout:

[z] 1x2.5 (Portrait)
[x] 1x2
[c] 1x1.5 (default in mobile)
[v] 1x1 Square
[b] 1.5x1 (Landscape, default in desktop)
[n] 2x1
[m] 2.5x1

May be unresponsive on higher resolutions (in those cases turning off the animation mode is recommended)

metadata.name: Shapes on a Plane #306
metadata.description:
‚ÄúShapes on a Plane‚Äù explores imaginary structures and worlds through simple shapes. It‚Äôs intended for small-scale print.

As a kid I was obsessed with Lego, Duplo, wooden building blocks... anything I could make something with.

I‚Äôd spend hours building things, imagining new worlds, new machines, new concepts, then i‚Äôd take them apart and create a whole new idea to explore.

To me, this piece to me is a reminder of that time - many days spent exploring ideas with those simple objects - no care for viability, for marketability, for audiences or business. Just pure fun.

Without this time in my life, I doubt I‚Äôd have found my passion for creating in the way I do today.

metadata.name: Latent~~~>Gradient #77
metadata.description: Latent patterns employ ‚Äònoise‚Äô generated by an evolutionary Neural Network to produce an endless symphonic combination of textures, color, materials and shapes resulting from navigating the network‚Äôs latent space.

metadata.name: System Œ± #211
metadata.description:
"To capture the fleeting time in the generating process."

In this work,I d'like focus on the generating of generative art system itself rather than imitate some scene or style.
And with the flow of time, try to figure out where it can take me toward.

This work would be a series of my alternative view on generative art.
"Œ±" means the first step of this series.

Press [s] in live view to save file as PNG.
Press [p] to stop.

------
Happy first birthday fx(hash) !!

20% of primary revenues go to Savepakistan Flood Relief Fundraiser.
20% of primary revenues go to the Processing foundation.
